1. 

Agriculture in the Northern Region 

 
The  Lao  PDR  is  one  of  the  poorest  countries  in  the  Mekong  region,  with  an  estimated 
2. 
per capita income of $310. The total population of the country is 5.5 million, of whom about 30% 
live below the national poverty line.2 While sound progress in reducing poverty is being made, 
the strategic thrust and priority of the country’s long-term socioeconomic development remains 
the  reduction  of  the  prevailing  high  poverty  incidence.  To  this  end,  the  Government  has 
developed  the  National  Growth  and  Poverty  Eradication  Strategy  (NGPES)  and  aims  to 
graduate from least-developed country status by 2020. The country strategy and program of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  is  oriented  to  helping  implement  the  NGPES,  including  the 
preparation  of  the  Northern  Region  Development  Strategy,  which  highlights  the  geographic 
advantage and growing trading opportunities in the northern region with neighboring countries. 
Bordering southern People’s Republic of China (PRC), Myanmar, Thailand, and Viet Nam, the 
northern region has been historically the central hub for regional trade that connects important 
routes  between  the  PRC  and  Southeast  Asia.  With  the  recent  substantial  development  of  the 
region’s  road  network,  regional  agricultural  trade  offers  increasingly  tangible  business 
opportunities for some agricultural commodities (para. 23).  
 
Agriculture  is  the  mainstay  of  the  Lao  PDR,  accounting  for  50%  of  gross  domestic 
3. 
product  (GDP)  and  employing  80%  of  the  total  labor  force.  While  the  sector  covers  various 
economic activities ranging from rice farming for subsistence to agro-processing industries, rice 
cultivation is the single most prevalent economic activity in the country, and rice is grown over 
about 639,000 hectares (ha), or 72% of the total cultivated area. Rice is the staple food source, 
which  accounts  for  about  67%  of  daily  calorie  intake  for  much  of  the  rural  population.  The 
agriculture sector’s development has significant implications for poverty reduction efforts in the 
country,  as  the  overwhelming  majority  of  the  rural  population  are  subsistence  farmers  (75%), 
who  experience  on  average  4  months  of  rice  insufficiency  a  year.  Over  the  past  decade,  the 
development  of  irrigation  facilities  has  been  the  driving  force  of  agricultural  growth  in  the 
country, and increased irrigated crop production, particularly during the dry season, has helped 
lift national rice production to the level of self-sufficiency. However, significant rice insufficiency 
at the household level persists, particularly in the northern region, due to the low productivity of 
the land in the region and the low degree of integration among various domestic markets and 
distribution systems in the country.  
 
Poverty  incidence  in  the  northern  region  is  high  at  53%.  A  population  of  just  over 
4. 
2 million  live  in  the  northern  region,  and  currently  little  more  than  10%  of  the  population  are 
urbanized. Farmers in the northern region typically face up to 6 months of rice insufficiency in a 
year. Limited farmland and its low productivity have kept upland communities in a state of food

Past investments made to rehabilitate community-managed irrigation (CMI) schemes in 
the  country  have  demonstrated  their  effectiveness  in  improving  food  security  and  rural 
livelihoods  by  strengthening  the  self-help  capacity  of  rural  communities  in  mountainous  rural 
areas.  The  Community-Managed 
the 
rehabilitation  of  47  small-scale  CMI  schemes  with  a  command  area  of  3,720  ha,  and  reduced 
poverty among project beneficiaries by generating substantial increases in household incomes 
and  per  capita  paddy  production  in  the  project  area.11  The  incremental  agricultural  activities 
were derived from an expanded cropping area, enhanced crop yields, and crop diversification.12 
Such  a  community-driven  poverty  reduction  approach  is  central  to  the  NGPES,  which 
encourages  investments  to  modernize  agricultural  production  of  poor  farmers  so  as  to  meet

Sustainability of Community-Managed Irrigation Schemes 

 
10. 
Notwithstanding  the  viability  of  CMI  schemes  in  enhancing  agricultural  production,  the 
sustainable  operation  of  CMI  schemes  beyond  the  period  of  funding  agency  investments  has 
been  a  major  challenge  for  the  Government,  major  funding  agencies,  and  nongovernment 
organizations in the sector (Appendix 3). In general, small weirs for CMI are designed to meet 
the  once-in-50-year  flood  criteria  in  the  country.  The  sustainability  of  rehabilitated  irrigation 
schemes depends largely on (i) continuous participation of communities in water management 
and  O&M  of  the  schemes,  (ii) technical  and  management  ability  of  water  user  associations 
(WUAs),  (iii) ability  of  local  government  agencies  to  provide  required  support  to  WUAs, 
(iv) financial affordability by farmers, and (v) watershed protection to minimize siltation of weirs 
and  canals.  While  the  fiscal  budget  allocation  for  O&M  of  irrigation  schemes  is  inadequate  to 
cover  the  requirements  of  all  irrigation  schemes,  much  of  the  physical  and  financial 
requirements for O&M can be met by community contributions.

At present, WUAs collect a level of ISFs affordable to farmers without giving adequate 
consideration to the estimated cost of long-term maintenance. WUAs collect and deposit ISFs in 
bank accounts to be utilized for future maintenance expenditures. The current ISF level may risk 
the  sustainability  of  rehabilitated  irrigation  schemes  since  the  amounts  collected  may  not  be 
enough  for  future  maintenance  works.  Feasibility  studies  of  potential  subprojects  illustrate  the 
amount that farmers can afford for ISFs that cover the cash expenditures on both routine and 
periodic  maintenance—approximately  KN189,000  per  ha,  which  accounts  for  about  10%  of 
expected  incremental  financial  net  income  per  ha.  Therefore,  ISF  collection  performance 
depends largely on farmers’ willingness to pay. Hence, it is indispensable that local government 
agencies (i) provide adequate technical assistance for participating communities in selecting the 
least-cost  option  by  estimating  future  O&M  costs;  and  (ii) during  the  initial  discussions,  clearly 
explain  to  communities,  and  confirm  their  willingness  to  pay,  the  routine  and  periodic 
maintenance costs for which they will be responsible.  
 
14. 
Community Management Capacity. Upgrading of traditional irrigation schemes without 
changing the basic designs has proven to be the best way to minimize institutional challenges 
imposed  on  the  use  of  rehabilitated  schemes  in  the  Lao  PDR.  The  vast  majority  of  CMI 
rehabilitation investments just replaced traditional weirs with permanent structures at the same 
locations  and  extended  existing  canals  because  farmers  are  used  to  the  existing  schemes, 
easily  understand  the  benefit  of  upgrading,  and  already  have  management  systems  for  the 
diversion  and  distribution  of  irrigation  water  over  the  command  areas.  Many  traditional  weirs 
have been constructed with village initiatives and are well maintained by communities under the 
leadership of village chiefs, despite a high labor requirement for frequent repairs. In contrast, the 
management  of  rehabilitated  schemes  requires  more  careful  O&M  planning,  as  some  cash 
expenditures for imported materials are required for periodic maintenance works, which need to 
be  financed  through  the  collection  of  ISFs.  In  order  for  WUAs  to  improve  their  capacity  to 
manage the planning required, technical assistance of local government agencies is essential, 
particularly  in  (i) planning  ISF  collection  based  on  estimated  O&M  expenditures,  and 
(ii) managing  the  collected  ISF  funds.  The  establishment  of  a  system  that  allows  farmers  to 
evaluate  the  management  of  village  activities  is  also  indispensable  to  maintain  transparency 
and farmers’ incentives to sustain the irrigation development activities.15  
 
15. 
Community Solidarity Development. It is important to combine livelihood improvement 
activities  that  are  complementary  to  irrigation development,  ensure  an  equitable  distribution  of 
benefits  generated  within  each  community,  and  provide  incentives  for  the  whole  village  to 
participate in irrigation development initiatives. Irrigation interventions alone tend to exclude the 
most vulnerable groups within participating villages, as the poorest farmers usually have limited 
access to irrigable land. Exclusion of the poorest groups has risks of worsening the inequalities 
that  already  exist  in  communities,  as  well  as  affecting  the  development  of  sustainable 
community organizations necessary for the long-term O&M of irrigation facilities. By combining 
village  livelihood  activities,  irrigation  rehabilitation  can  also  assist  in  forming  a  new  leadership 
within participating communities that represents wider interests of villagers (Appendix 4).

Integration  of  Catchment  Rehabilitation  Activities.  Streams  in  mountainous  areas 
are  frequently  experiencing  shorter  and  higher  wet-season  flows,  and  longer  and  lower  dry-

1. 

Community Mobilization Component 

 
29. 
The  community  mobilization  component  will  formulate  the  social  bases  for  identifying, 
planning, and implementing sustainable irrigation schemes; various community activities will be 
introduced  as  a  first  step.  This  process  will  provide  farmers  with  incentives  for  active 
participation  in  the  Project  by  immediately  benefiting  all  in  the  participating  communities,  and 
promote farmers with common interests to commence collective community activities in groups. 
During the initial stage, options for community activities, such as agricultural extension services 
for irrigated land and uplands, rural access road upgrading, and rural water supply schemes, will 
be  presented  to  participating  villages  to  allow  them  to  select  and  plan  implementation  and 
maintenance arrangements. This process will allow time to interact with the communities to gain 
a better understanding of potential irrigation facility rehabilitation and other project activities. The 
component  will  be  implemented  according  to  the  community  participation  development  plan. 
Farmer  production  groups  and  water  user  groups  (WUGs)  are  expected  to  emerge  as  the 
participating villages implement community-related initiatives.  
 
30.  Where there are needs for improved rural water supply facilities, the Project will support 
the development of hillside springs and reticulate water to selected points within the villages, as 
well  as  the  construction  of  sanitary  wells,  which  would  be  lined  with  concrete  rings  and  fitted 
with simple suction hand pumps. As the social organization required for planning and managing 
domestic  water  supply  schemes  is  similar  to  that  required  for  WUAs,  the  Project  will  assist  in 
establishing WUGs to manage both irrigation and domestic water to enable a holistic approach 
to  water  resource  management,  where  feasible.  The  construction  of  deep  wells  with  high-lift 
pumps  will  not  be  considered  due  to  (i) high  cost,  (ii) difficulty  in  reaching  remote  sites  with 
construction  equipment,  (iii) lack  of  hydrogeological  information,  and  (iv) lack  of  arrangements 
for the maintenance of wells and pumps.  
 
31. 
The Project expects to finance the upgrading of a total of about 30 km of village access 
roads  to  link  irrigation  schemes  and  project  communities  with  the  closest  road  networks.  The 
better road access is a critical factor to lead the irrigation development and extension activities 
to enhanced agricultural production. Road design standards will be in accordance with the new 
Class  VIII  standards  for  roads,  with  average  daily  traffic  of  less  than  20.31  Based  on  the 
International  Labour  Organization’s  guidelines  for  labor-based  road  construction,  simplified 
technical  specifications  and  bidding  documents  will  be  used  to  avoid  complexity  and  reduce 
construction costs.

Community-Managed Irrigation Investment Component 

 
The  Project  expects  to  rehabilitate  about  30  irrigation  schemes,  and  the  scope  of  civil 
33.

and  stone  masonry),  (ii) improvement  of  canal  systems  with  reinforced  concrete  canal

knowledge  of  the  project  area  will  improve  the  quality  of  design  works,  minimize  potential 
resettlement  impacts,  and  ensure  that  the  proposed  CMI  scheme  is  in  line  with  farmers’

35.  With  other  ongoing  extension  development  initiatives  in  the  country  (para.  21),  the 
extension  assistance  will  cover  both  irrigated  lowland  rice  production  and  upland  cropping. 
Production technologies for cash crops will be included where feasible. Participating villages will 
be exposed to demonstrations and new production technologies applicable to local conditions in 
the  project  villages.  Field  demonstrations  will  be  carried  out  based  on  a  participatory  needs 
assessment in each participating village to ensure that the service addresses the priority needs 
of  poor  farmers,  in  conjunction  with  the  community  mobilization  component.  Potential 
agricultural  extension  service  packages  will  include  improved  rice-production  technologies, 
livestock  production  and  management,  crop  diversification,  sloping-land  production 
technologies, integrated pest management and weed control, nursery establishment for fruit and 
timber  trees,  storage  and  postharvest  management  technologies,  and  an  introduction  to 
potential  high-value  cash  crops  where  markets  exist.  The  upland  extension  technology 
packages will be selected based on the communities’ needs and the nature and potential of the 
uplands  peripheral  to  the  irrigable  land.  Catchment  rehabilitation  for  schemes  adjacent  to 
irrigation areas will be included in the upland extension packages as appropriate.

Gender Issues. While women traditionally play a major role in irrigation-related activities 
and all parts of the rice-cropping cycle, women in the project area are disadvantaged relative to

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

Project Benefits 

A. 
 
The most important overall impact of the Project will be an increase in food production 
56. 
and the potential for raising household incomes of poor households. By upgrading small-scale 
irrigation  schemes,  the  Project  is  expected  to  (i) ensure  better  irrigation  water  management, 
thereby increasing wet-season paddy yields; (ii) enable crop diversification and double cropping 
in the dry season; (iii) reduce the workload for the regular repair of diversion weirs; (iv) halt the 
cutting down of trees for weir repairs; and (v) expand the irrigation command areas for both the 
wet and dry seasons as a result of better diversion control and improved distribution systems. 
Approximately  30  irrigation  schemes  will  be  rehabilitated  involving  about  1,900  ha  of  irrigated 
command  area.  A  financial  analysis  has  estimated  substantial  incremental  financial  income  to 
be generated in the sample subprojects, indicating that induced disposable farmer incomes can 
be highly positive in the project area. The economic internal rates of return for the subprojects 
have  been  calculated  at  12–19%.  The  calculated  quantifiable  cropping  benefits  demonstrate 
that  substantial  economic  incentives  exist  for  farmers  to  diversify  crop  production,  once  they 
satisfy  their  subsistence  needs.  Sensitivity  and  risk  analyses  on  extreme  scenarios  have 
indicated that the results of economic analysis are fairly robust and exposed to marginal risk in 
all but the case of the Nam Pa Subproject in Luang Prabang province (Appendix 12).  
 
B. 
 
57. 
 The  Project  will  directly  assist  those  in  poor  villages  in  the  northern  region,  who  are 
suffering  from  food  shortages  by  increasing  agricultural  production  through  the  provision  of 
improved facilities for wet- and dry-season irrigation, combined with the introduction of improved 
farming methods and better physical access. In total, around 37,000 rural villagers are expected 
to  benefit  from  the  Project,39  of  whom  at  least  60%  are  poor  farmers.40  The  estimated  2,700 
households in the project area, who already have access to lowlands suitable for irrigation, will 
be  the  main  project  beneficiaries.  They  are  subsistence  farmers  who  face  an  average  of  4 
months of food insufficiency per year, and sometimes practice shifting cultivation in the uplands 
to  meet  their  subsistence  needs.41  The  Project  is  expected  to  reduce  food  shortages  from  an 
increase in irrigated agriculture production, and consequently their swidden agriculture practices 
are  expected  to  be  substantially  reduced.  At  the  same  time,  approximately  4,800  households 
that  do  not  have  access  to  irrigated  land  will  benefit  directly  from  increased  agricultural 
production in the uplands, community infrastructure improvements, and watershed management 
activities,  and  indirectly  from  increased  agricultural  employment  opportunities  induced  by  the 
Project. Ethnic minority groups and women in particular are expected to benefit directly from the 
Project due to the proactive measures to encourage their participation facilitated by CLOs and 
priority targeting and monitoring of project activities for them.

2. 

Investment Demand 

 
2. 
With their traditional irrigation schemes, farmers in the project area are currently suffering 
from  (i) frequent  damage  to  the  schemes  by  floods  that  require  labor  works  and  materials  for 
repair several times a year; (ii) low efficiency of existing weirs particularly during the dry season; 
and (iii) low capacity of existing weirs in expanding command areas. Over the last 20 years, the 
experience  of  major  funding  agencies  in  the  sector  demonstrated  that  the  replacement  of 
traditional  weirs  by  permanent  structures  could  effectively  improve  efficiency  of  water  use  and 
reduce  substantially  the  labor  requirement  for  repairs.  In  general,  this  assistance  for  small-scale 
community-managed  irrigation  schemes  has  been  successful  because  they  simply  improve  a 
traditional system,  already  well  known  to farmers,  as  opposed  to trying to introduce  entirely new 
concepts  such  as  pumping  irrigation.  Upgrading  small-scale  schemes  without  changing  the 
traditional  gravity-fed  design  has  also  allowed  most  of  poor  farming  communities  to  operate  the 
upgraded  schemes  in  a  sustainable  manner,  because  of  its  relatively  economical  expenditure 
requirements  of  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M). 1  Any  schemes  that  require  high  cash 
expenditures for O&M cannot be sustainable where the scope for cash crop development is limited 
due to rice deficiency, small dry-season flow, and limited access to local markets. 
 
3. 
The total investment required for the civil works of the 73 schemes in the long list, including 
survey,  design,  and  supervision,  is  estimated  to  be  about  $10.3 million.2 Given  the  size  of  the 
financing resources, the Project is expected to finance about 30 subprojects. In order to facilitate 
active  community  participation  throughout  the  project  implantation  period  and  to  ensure 
sustainability and community ownership in the process, the Project needs to invest in community 
institution-building  efforts  and  extension  assistance  to  complement  the  impacts  of  the  irrigation 
investment as well.

Land Tenure. Unclear allocation of land use rights of sloping lands is a major constraint to 
permanent and sustainable cultivation of sloping-land and catchment area protection activities in 
rural  villages.  This  prevents  communities  from  optimizing  the  use  of  available  production 
resources.  Upland  areas  surrounding  the  lowlands  and  community  land  suited  to  sustainable 
agricultural  use  is  often  not  used  effectively,  mainly  due  to  a  lack  of  mechanisms  to  allocate 
user rights for such land, thereby discouraging its productive use by farmers. The Land Law of 
June 1997 specifies that the national community owns land, and individuals have the right to use 
land,  provided  they  use  it  continuously  and  effectively.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  is 
responsible  for  land  management  including  land  registration,  land  titling,  and  leasing.  Although 
MOF  has  started  issuing  land  ownership  titles  supported  by  the  land  titling  project  of  the  World 
Bank, the project assistance focuses only on titling of irrigable lowlands and it will take many years 
before land titling becomes available in the remote mountainous villages. With regard to land use 
rights,  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Forestry  (MAF)  is  authorized  to  issue  land  certificates  to 
legally indicate user rights for those who have used land continuously for a period of 3 years for 
agricultural  production.  The  allocation  of  such  land  use  rights  is  the  responsibility  of  district 
administrations. These land certificates are initially issued to families for a period of 3 years, and 
subsequently  the  families  will  retain  the  rights  to  the  use  of  the  lands  provided  they  continue  to 
farm the lands.5 As land use certificates are not issued for sloping lands, farmers do not have any

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR):  
 
The Government’s goals are to reduce poverty by 50% by 2005, to eradicate it by 2010, and to enable the Lao People's 
Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) to graduate from being a least developing country to a developing country by 2020. The 
Country  Strategy  and  Program  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for  the  Lao  PDR  and  the  poverty  reduction 
partnership  agreement  signed  by  the  Government  and  ADB  in  2001  state  that  efforts  will  be  directed  toward  reducing 
poverty  by  broadening  community  participation  and  opportunities  during  the  next  5  years.  The  operational  priorities  to 
achieve  these  goals  are  (i) rural  development  and  market  linkages,  (ii) human  resource  development,  (iii) sustainable 
environmental management, and (iv) regional integration. The Project aims to contribute to these operational priorities by 
(i) improving  food  production  by  developing  cost-effective  and  sustainable  farmer  managed  irrigation  schemes, 
(ii) enhancing  human  development  by  providing  the  enabling  environment  for  more  effective  community  participation  in 
rural  development  activities,  (iii) environmentally  appropriate  extension  activities  in  the  uplands  promoting  sustainable 
environmental management of local resources, and (iv) promotion of regional integration via support for a more farmer-
centered agricultural extension service.

What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Of an estimated population of 5.5 million in the Lao PDR, about 30% live below the poverty 
line. This is defined as being where a person cannot access the equivalent of 2,100 calories 
in foodstuffs or the equivalent of KN142,500 per month or less than US$0.50 per day. The 
Lao  PDR  defines  this  as  the  food  poverty  line.  The  Lao  PDR  also  differentiates  between 
average  poverty  lines  for  urban  and  rural  areas  and  between  different  regions.  The  per 
capita per month poverty line is upward of 30% higher in Vientiane than in the rural areas of 
the Lao PDR. The poorest province in the project area is the northern province of Huaphanh 
(74.6%),  followed  by  Xaysomboun  Special  Region  (55%),  Luang  Prabang  (49.4%), 
Xiengkhuang  (34.9%)  and  Xayabury  (21.2%)  living  below  the  poverty  line.  For  the  project 
area as a whole an estimated 45% of the population lives in poverty. If the urban population 
is excluded in these provinces over half the rural population is living in poverty. The project 
area  also  contains  some  of  the  severest  forms  of  poverty  (ultra-poor)  in  the  Lao  PDR. 
Huaphanh has the most severe form of poverty (11.3% of people) followed by Xaysomboun 
Special Region (7.1%) and Luang Prabang (4.7%). The regional percentage at 6.8% is the 
highest in the Lao PDR (4%) . 

 
For  the  selected  districts  in  the  project  area  the  incidence  of  poverty  ranges  from  88%  in 
Sobbao  (Huaphanh)  to  13.6%  in  Thong  Mixay  (Xayabury).  However,  in  the  latter  district 
there  are  villages  where  the  incidence  of  poverty  is  quite  high  (44%).  Additionally  in  the 
other  district  of  Xayabury—despite  the  relatively  low  incidence  of  poverty  on  a  provincial 
basis (in part due to its close proximity to Thailand)—there are several villages that would 
likely  be included in this Project  with  a  high incidence  of poverty (over 60%). Typically  all 
districts in the project area have some villages where the incidence of poverty is quite low 
and other villages where it is quite high. Villages or those households in villages that have 
access to allocated land or land that could be allocated for irrigation are somewhat better 
off than villages or those  households  within  the  same villages that do not have  access  to 
lowland  suitable  for  irrigation.  The  subprojects  would  likely  include  such  villages  or  a 
combination of villages. 
  
Rice-deficit  months  have  been  used  as  one  of  the  key  quantitative  indexes  to  assess  the 
extent  of  poverty  in  the  project  area.  Of  the  different  ethnic  groups  where  over  80%  of 
households  are  classified  as  poor  it  is  more  likely  that  the  lowland  Lao  and  Hmong 
experience  some  form  of  rice  shortage.  However,  in  all  other  villages  where  over  20%  of 
households are living in poverty these villages are likely to be where the Khmou are found 
in  the  majority.  The  Khmou  nationally  have  an  average  rice  sufficiency  of  5.9  months

People  have  a  conception  of  household  food  security  that  goes  beyond  simply  having 
sufficient food  to feed household members. It also  includes access to safe drinking  water, 
secure access to land forest and water resources, security for their livestock, the capacity to 
send their children to school every day or on most days, and to provide a buffer against life 
crises.  It  also  importantly  includes  adequate  material  and  symbolic  resources  to  fully 
participate in the religious and ritual activities in local communities and  meet other kinship 
obligations  such  as  providing  support  for  close  kindred  experiencing  material  hardship. 
Where  exclusion  occurs  as  a  result  of  not  being  in  a  position  to  fully  participate  in  local 
community  life  a  form  of  social  exclusion,  which  is  one  of  the  key  qualitative  indicators  of 
poverty,  often  occurs.  For  ethnic  minorities  unable  to  speak  the  national  language  of  the 
Lao  PDR  this  is  also  a  form  of  social  exclusion  that  exacerbates  poverty.  Upward  of  only 
40% of Khmou are literate (male 60.8%, female 2.7%) and 26.5% of Hmong (male 45.7%, 
female 8.1%) compared to the Lao PDR rate of 72.9% (male 84.4%, female 65.1%). 
 
The  Project  adopts  a  pro-poor  approach  and  the  components  have  been  designed  to 
benefit people living in poverty. To ensure that the poor are among the beneficiaries, each 
subproject will provide a range of agricultural extension packages based on the priorities of 
the poor within each of the subproject communities, most of whom are likely to be involved 
in upland agricultures. Community-level organizers (CLO: female and male including where 
relevant from ethnic minority backgrounds) will be appointed for the duration of subproject 
implementation  to  facilitate  the  targeting  of  women  and  ethnic  minority  groups.  People 
living  in  poverty  will  be  afforded  the  opportunity  to  actively  participate  in  water  user 
associations (WUAs), especially in subproject areas where rural water supply interventions 
are supported by the Project. This is likely to reduce the social distance between better-off 
households  and  households  living  in  poverty.  The  Project  will  also  provide  an  enabling 
environment  for  district  agriculture  and  forestry  service  office  (DAFSO)  and  district  Lao 
Women's  Union  (DLWU)  to  work  more  closely  with  poor  households  on  designing 
appropriate extension packages that will directly benefit the poor. Sharpening of the poverty 
focus  will  also  enable  provincial  agriculture  and  forestry  service  office  (PAFSO)  and 
DAFSO to more effectively target households living in poverty in order to meet the overall 
poverty reduction strategy of the Lao PDR.

Is there a participation strategy? 
 
During  the  feasibility  study  stage,  and  from  the  lessons  of  CMIS,  it  was  realized  that  substantial  time  and  effort  are 
required to  adopt a fully participatory  process in the design and development of  not  just  the irrigation schemes but the 
extension-related  activities  in  both  upland  and  lowland  areas  of  the  subproject  area.  Without  systemic  community 
mobilization  via  water  user  groups  that  involve  the  equal  membership  of  both  women  and  men,  operation  and 
maintenance  (O&M)  responsibilities  and  ownership  of  irrigation  schemes  will  be  nonsustainable.  Equally,  agricultural 
extension and land use planning-based activities that are not designed in accordance with the full and active participation 
of primary stakeholders are unlikely to be very successful. The participation strategy is also premised on synergies being 
achieved  between  DAFSO  extension  workers,  including  female  extension  workers,  and  local  farmer  production  groups 
that are more appropriate in the context of upland farming systems in the project area than has hitherto been possible. 
However,  the  participation  strategy  also  demands  of  stakeholder  groups,  especially  PAFSO,  a  better  understanding  of 
social  and  gender  issues  than  exists  at  present.  Iterative  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  the  participation  strategy  will 
require systematic attention to both quantitative indexes of participation (such as the frequency of attendance at meetings 
by  vulnerable  groups)  and  qualitative  indexes  of  participation  (such  as  to  what  extent  vulnerable  groups  were  able  to 
raise relevant issues and have them accepted by other group members). 
 
A  project-specific  community  participation  development  plan  has  been  prepared.  Essentially  it  starts  from  the  premise 
that unless local communities are prepared to take ownership for project interventions, including participation of women 
and  men  stakeholders  (and  ethnic  minorities)  then  support  will  not  be  given  to  that  community.  However,  once  a 
community agrees with the objectives of the subproject—to be supported by a series of appropriate information sessions 
explaining these objectives—the Project will provide the enabling environment via the appointment of both a female and 
male CLO (and where appropriate an ethnic minority CLO will also be appointed). The principal tasks of these CLOs will 
be to work with their own local communities and be the linkage with the village committees, DAFSO, and DLWU. They 
will receive appropriate training in social mobilization, including mobilization strategies for women and ethnic minorities, 
and  will  be  expected  to  provide  appropriate  training  to  beneficiaries  at  the  village  level.  Their  performance  will  be 
monitored  by  both  their  own  local  community  and  an  external  monitoring  agency,  which  is  likely  to  be  the  DLWU. 
Community  mobilization  will  be  considered  successful  if  during  subproject  implementation  as  many  opportunities  as 
possible are afforded to local communities to play an active role in actual implementation. If local communities are able to 
contribute to the survey and design of irrigation schemes, provide the appropriate inputs such as labor contributions for 
land  clearing,  contribute  to  the  development  and  maintenance  of  WUA,  and  demonstrate  ownership  by  taking 
responsibility  for  O&M,  then  the  participatory  component  of  the  subproject  will  be  considered  successful.  The  same 
caveats apply to the agricultural extension and land use planning component. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Women’s  interests  can  be  at  risk  if  they  (i) miss  out  on  technical  and  organizational  innovations  that  come  with  the 
Project; (ii) miss out on the benefits of the Project; and (iii) are left out of the decision-making processes,  which affects 
their  lives,  including  labor  and  livelihood  issues.  The  Project  will  entail  efforts  to  ensure  that  women  and  men  benefit 
equally from the Project, and that the Project’s participatory processes are used as an experiential learning model from 
which lessons can be learned for the gender and development processes in the Lao PDR. The Project’s gender strategy 
aims to (i) mitigate the risk that women will be disadvantaged by project interventions (e.g., design of irrigation schemes 
or  irrigation  packages  are  gender  sensitive);  (ii) ensure  women’s  participation  in  community  dialogue  and  partnering 
activities (e.g., meetings and farmer exchanges on an equal basis with men); (iii) ensure equal representation of women 
(at  least  50%  representation)  in  WUG;  (iv) promote  men  working  with  women  in  the  Project  (e.g.,  on-farm  crop 
productivity improvement trials); (v) prioritize women’s needs (e.g., DAFSO extension officers providing training in fields 
requested  by  women  such  as  animal  health  interventions);  and  (vi) facilitate  gender  training  and  integration  programs 
with the assistance of the DLWU (e.g., gender and development programs targeted at both men and women at the village 
level and PAFSO/DAFSO). 
 
There are significant differences in women’s social and economic status between the different ethnic groups. Unlike the 
Hmong and Khmou, Lowland Lao society  has a matrifocal bias, in  which daughters generally inherit household assets, 
including land. This should mean that Lowland Lao women can make decisions about how land is going to be utilized or 
how  water  is  going  to  be  managed.  However,  generally  speaking  women  at  the  village  level  are  not  equal  partners  in

Introduction 

 
A. 
 
1. 
The  Houay  Lor  Irrigation  scheme  (the  Subproject)  is  one  of  the  four  core  subprojects 
selected for feasibility level study as a basis for the preparation of the Lao Northern Community-
Managed Irrigation Sector Loan (the Project) proposed for financing by the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB). The subproject site is located in the Nam Bak district, approximately 8 kilometers 
(km)  east  of  Nam  Bak,  Luang  Prabang  province.  An  environmental  management  plan  (EMP) 
has been prepared for the Project as a whole, and describes the environmental assessment and 
review framework that will be applied to all subprojects (Supplementary Appendix C). 
 
2. 
The  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  for  the  Subproject  was  undertaken  during 
the  project  preparation  work.  It  entailed  a  review  of  possible  design  options  and  proposed 
project  area  and  its  environs,  field observations  within  and  around  the  proposed  scheme,  and 
interviews with a variety of groups. At the time of the IEE, a proposed final design had yet to be 
determined but this, in fact, turned out to be a positive factor since it allowed the results of the 
IEE  to  be  taken  into  consideration  in  reviewing  and  formulating  design  and  development 
options.  The  Project  as  a  whole  and  its  major  environmental  and  social  impacts  have  been 
widely discussed between July 2002 and July 2003 during 36 focused village group discussions, 
and  the  socioeconomic  surveys  that  involved  113  villages  in  the  northern  provinces.  Further 
beneficiary consultations will be carried out for the detailed survey and design of subprojects in 
order  to  minimize  any  social  and  environmental  adverse  impacts  and  to  design  schemes  that 
meet beneficiaries' needs and expectations. 
 
B.  
 
3. 
The Subproject seeks to develop the small-scale community-managed irrigation scheme 
with  the  objective  to  improve  the  livelihood  of  poor  farming  communities  through  sustainable 
irrigation  development.  The  Subproject  is  in  line  with  government  agriculture  development 
policies that focus, amongst others, on stable food production, mitigation of shifting cultivation, 
and  on  curbing  and  reversing  watershed  degradation.  It  is  recognized  that  small-scale, 
community-managed irrigation agriculture is to play a key role in attaining these objectives.  
 
The  Houay  Lor  scheme  is  an  existing  farmers’  managed  irrigation  scheme  with  a 
4. 
command area of 50 hectares (ha). The proposed subproject will entail the replacement of three 
existing  small  wood  and  rock  diversion  weirs  by  three  permanent  run-of-the-river  weirs.  The 
weirs will be small in size. Left and right main canals will be constructed with a total length of 
6.0 km,  of  which  4 km  existing  canals  and  2 km  new  canals.  This  would  allow  a  wet-season 
extension of the irrigated area by 30 ha, from 50 to 80 ha. The dry-season irrigation potential will 
stay the same at 14 ha. The canals will be hand-dug, although some rock sections may require 
heavy  equipment.  The  canals  will  be  unlined,  and  provided  with  passageways  at  selected 
places. Canal heads, canal banks passing through unstable soil, as well as stream banks just 
below the weir will be reinforced with concrete and rip-rap to prevent scouring.

estimated  rainy  season  flow  of  1–2  cubic  meters  per  second  (m³/s),  and  an  estimated  dry-

Environmental Impacts Resulting from Project Operations 

 
12. 
It  is  expected  that  only  one  potential  problem  has  been  identified  for  the  project 
operation phase, which is the question of downstream water quality for human consumption due 
to the increased use of pesticides and chemical fertilizer. Irrigation development is expected to 
result in an increase of farmers' incomes, and consequently, in increased use of pesticides and 
chemical fertilizer. 
 
13. 
Currently, use of pesticides in the Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) is still 
relatively low, although in recent years the share of farmers using pesticides has increased from 
25%  to  56%.  There  are  two  factors  that  warrant  vigilance  on  future  use  of  these  compounds: 
(i) the Lao PDR is bordered by three pesticide-exporting countries—People’s Republic of China, 
Thailand,  and  Viet  Nam—and  manufacturing  companies  have  their  own  promotion  programs; 
and (ii) farmers in the Lao PDR have insufficient knowledge of safe handling and application of 
pesticides,  which  may  lead  to  misuse.  However,  such  problems  could  be  mitigated  through 
strengthened  management  mechanism  as  well  as  implementing  water  quality  monitoring.  To 
mitigate this potential impact farmers will be trained on (i) the selection, safe use, and handling 
of  pesticides,  (ii) integrated  pest  management  (IPM),  and  (iii) personal  health  care  using  as  a 
reference  the  updated  Regulation  on  Conservation  and  Use  of  Pesticides  in  Lao PDR  (2000), 
which lists prohibited or restricted use of chemical compounds.

ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 

Introduction 

 
A. 
 
The goal of the Northern Community-Managed Irrigation Sector Project (the Project) is to 
1. 
reduce rural poverty through increased agricultural production and income earning opportunities 
in  the  project  area.  The  major  means  to  attain  these  goals  include  the  development  of  small-
scale  community-managed  irrigation  schemes  and  the  provision  of  agricultural  extension 
services  to  both  irrigated  farms  and  to  upland  cultivators  in  the  target  communities. 
Approximately  30  subprojects  covering  roughly  1,900  irrigated  hectares  (ha)  in  11  districts 
located  in  Luang  Prabang,  Sayaboury,  Xieng  Khouang,  and  Houaphan  provinces  and 
Xaisomboun Special Zone will be selected for the project financing according to the subproject 
selection criteria. 
 
B. 
 
For  the  quantified  analysis,  benefits  and  costs  are  examined  based  on  “with”  and 
2. 
“without”  scenarios  for  20-year  life  of  the  Project.  With  the  provision  of  extension  services  as 
well  as  increased  and  more  reliable  irrigation  water  “with”  the  Project,  it  is  expected  that 
improved farmers’ choices of crops and technologies will enable a more productive agriculture 
in  the  subproject  areas.  Quantifiable  direct  benefits  of  the  Project  are  comprised  largely  of 
incremental production of irrigated rice and higher-valued dry-season vegetable crops as well as 
improved  maize  in  the  upland  areas  surrounding  each  community.  Some  operation  and 
maintenance  (O&M)  cost  saving  is  also  expected  as  the  project  weirs  will  replace  wood  and 
stone  weirs,  for  which  O&M  costs  (in  timber  and  labor)  are  very  high.  As  available  timber 
becomes  progressively  distant,  it  is  assumed  that  these  O&M  costs  would  increase  2%  per 
year. 
 

Methodology 

1. 

Price Assumptions 

3. 
Financial prices used in the analysis were identified through a survey of the subproject 
areas and crosschecked with prices noted in a variety of secondary sources. Economic prices of 
traded goods, such as rice, maize, and fertilizers, have been estimated at boarder parity based 
on  World  Bank  commodity  price  projections.  The  investment  and  recurrent  costs  were 
segregated into tradable, nontraded, and labor components, and converted into economic price 
using financial process net of taxes, duties, and subsidies. The economic analysis is presented 
in  2002  constant  terms,  and  economic  cost  and  benefits  are  estimated  using  the  world  price 
numeraire.  A  prevailing  exchange  rate  of  KN10,800  per  US  dollar  has  been  used  for  the 
analysis.  For  nontraded  goods  and  services,  economic  prices  have  been  calculated  based  on 
local financial prices adjusted by a standard conversion factor (SCF) of 0.9 and a shadow wage 
rate (SWR) factor of 0.8 are used for rural labor in the farm budgets in order to reflect average 
levels of rural underemployment in the Lao People's Democratic Republic.
